author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Rory McIlroy Has a Big Day at the British Open. Viktor Hovland Follows.
description: McIlroy leapfrogged to the top of the leaderboard with a stunning bunker shot on No. 10 for eagle. He and Hovland were tied heading into the final round on Sunday.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland —- Standing in one of the Old Course’s 112 bunkers on Saturday, Rory McIlroy was about to be right where he wanted to be: atop the leaderboard of the British Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Unpredictable Maryland Governor’s Race Pits Old Guard vs. Upstarts
description: Will a deep-blue state elect another Republican governor to succeed Larry Hogan? Tuesday’s competitive primaries will signal where the race is headed.
content: SILVER SPRING, Md. — Tuesday’s primary elections for Maryland governor come at a moment when Democrats are jittery, unsure of the future and perhaps willing to bet on a flashy, unproven commodity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathleen Kingsbury
title: The New York Times Is Reimagining Sunday Review
description: “By renaming the section Sunday Opinion, we’re recognizing the role it plays and making that clearer to readers.”
content: This article also appears in the Opinion Today newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it in your inbox each weekday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Cowell
title: Eugenio Scalfari, Leading Italian Journalist, Dies at 98
description: As a founder of La Repubblica, one of the country’s major newspapers, and later as a columnist, he left a mark on civic life.
content: Eugenio Scalfari, one of Italy’s best-known journalists, who came to enduring prominence as a founder of the liberal newspaper La Repubblica, lobbing editorial salvos across the nation’s public life and over the high walls of the Vatican, died on Thursday in Rome. He was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By M. Leona Godin
title: ‘Is That Ableist?’ Good Question.
description: No one likes to be scolded for using the “wrong” language. But we must be willing to change our habits as attitudes and language change.
content: On a recent visit to my hometown, San Francisco, I met up with two fellow blind writer friends — Haben Girma and Caitlin Hernandez. Haben is a human rights lawyer and author, the first and only deaf-blind graduate of Harvard Law School. Caitlin is a talented teacher and young adult novelist. I’d been friends with her since we met in a writers’ group in 2017, when she dubbed herself my pet millennial because I’m about 20 years her senior. She and Haben are both in their early 30s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danya Issawi
title: Can’t Talk, I’m Busy Being Hot
description: A social media movement inspired by the rapper Megan Thee Stallion strikes back at the gatekeepers of beauty.
content: Edwyna Estime was wearing a heavy, shapeless graduation gown. It was the color of charcoal and it reached all the way down to her ankles. And yet she had never felt hotter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Deal With a Difficult Doorman
description: What bothers one person may not bother another, but when enough residents band together to complain, action often follows.
content: Q: My co-op building has a new doorman who does not perform his duties. He never opens the door. He leaves packages unattended and overnight in the lobby. He’s loud and indiscreet, converses on the phone, is often away from the desk and can be hostile and defiant to shareholders and guests. What recourse do shareholders have? Can we withhold the portion of maintenance that goes toward his salary if his performance does not improve?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: What It Means to See America in Person
description: Trading the online nation for the open road.
content: BIGFORK, Mont. — I’m writing these words early in a darkened motel room, 2,460 miles from home, eight hours east of Seattle and 45 minutes south of Glacier National Park. Around me five other people are still asleep: My wife and four children, crowded onto queen-size beds, an air mattress and a pack-and-play. These have been our conditions for the last 16 nights, which we have spent claiming an important American birthright: The westward migration via minivan, the great cross-country drive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: Jak Knight, Known for ‘Big Mouth’ Netflix Series, Dies at 28
description: Mr. Knight, who was a stand-up comedian, died on Thursday in Los Angeles, his family said.
content: Jak Knight, a stand-up comedian, writer and actor known for his role on the animated Netflix series “Big Mouth,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. He was 28.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein and Ava Sasani
title: What New Abortion Bans Mean for the Youngest Patients
description: One 10-year-old became the focus of debate, but more than 1,000 girls under 15 seek abortions each year. “How are we going to help the pregnant kids?”
content: She was just 10 years old, so young that many people were horrified when they heard it, and others refused to believe it. But the ordeal of the child rape victim in Ohio who had to cross state lines for an abortion, and the ugly political fight that followed, have highlighted two uncomfortable facts: Such pregnancies are not as rare as people think, and new abortion bans are likely to have a pronounced impact on the youngest pregnant girls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Allyson Felix’s victory lap wasn’t about the medal
description: Felix won yet another world championship medal, her 19th. “I think I felt all the emotions,” she said of her final competitive race.
content: Allyson Felix didn’t know exactly how she wanted to start or finish her farewell tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen Schulman
title: Post-Lockdown, I’m Learning to Let Go of My Young Adult Kids — Again
description: When my adult children came home during Covid lockdown, I loved like I could protect them.
content: Last week, when it had been more than two days since I’d heard from my young adult children — Zoë, 26, and Isaac, 23 — I sent a text to our family chat: “Smoke signals, please.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Texas Man Charged in Four Decades-Old California Murders
description: Officials said DNA evidence helped lead to the arrest of the man, who was charged in the 1980 and 1995 killings of three women and a teenager.
content: DNA evidence helped crack unsolved murders, some dating to 1980, of three women and a teenage girl in California, leading to the arrest of a 75-year-old man in Texas, the authorities said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Allison McCann and Josh Holder
title: How We Counted Egypt’s Invisible Detainees
description: There was no public accounting of the prisoners in the black hole of Egypt’s indefinite pretrial detention. Until now.
content: A New York Times investigation found that Egypt is holding thousands of people in a system of pretrial detention that can be extended indefinitely, stretching Egyptian laws limiting such detention and allowing the government to imprison people without having to prove its case in a trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Issues Subpoena to Secret Service in Hunt for Text Messages
description: The House committee is seeking messages that an inspector general for the Department of Homeland Security said had been erased.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the attack on the United States Capitol issued a subpoena to the Secret Service late Friday seeking text messages from Jan. 5 and 6, 2021, that were said to have been erased, as well as any after-action reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Can Galen Rupp outrun the shadow of a disgraced former coach?
description: Galen Rupp is the greatest American distance runner of his generation. For a long time, the disgraced coach Alberto Salazar guided him. Should that matter?
content: Galen Rupp is the greatest American distance runner of the 21st century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anupreeta Das
title: A Warren Buffett Protégée Strikes Out on Her Own
description: Tracy Britt Cool spent a decade working closely with the renowned investor. She is now applying those lessons to her own firm.
content: Tracy Britt Cool always knew she wanted to work in business. So, not unlike the star of a high school musical asking Steven Spielberg for a part, she figured she should start at the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Peter Baker
title: As Biden Reaches Out to Mideast Dictators, His Eyes Are on China and Russia
description: Looking to make Moscow pay for its Ukraine war, and box China out of Mideast tech deals, the U.S. president tries to fall back on old Gulf alliances.
content: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia — During his painful encounters with a series of Arab strongmen here in Saudi Arabia this weekend, President Biden kept returning to a single reason for renewing his relationship with American allies who fall on the wrong side of the struggle he often describes as a battle between “democracy and autocracy.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Isabella Kwai
title: Wildfires, and a Heat Wave, Sweep Across Europe
description: Fires in the south of France have burned more than 22,000 acres and prompted widespread evacuations. Britain was bracing for record high temperatures early next week.
content: Crews in the south of France were battling wildfires on Saturday that had consumed more than 22,000 acres and prompted the evacuation of 12,000 people, the local authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: They Couldn’t Believe Their Eyes: The Ocean Was Glowing.
description: Satellites previously detected a giant bioluminescent bloom in the Java Sea. Researchers found a boat crew that sailed through it.
content: Naomi McKinnon knew something was up, but she was not sure what. She went below deck for a minute, then rejoined her two crewmates on watch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Phillip Lopate
title: Picasso & Company: The Artists Who (Finally) Conquered America
description: Hugh Eakin’s new book, “Picasso’s War,” features plenty of cultural heroes and heroines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: Raving for Shrek, the Swamp Comes to Brooklyn
description: A party in East Williamsburg invited fans of the 2001 film to translate into reality their online obsessions with the titular ogre.
content: On a recent Friday night at the Brooklyn Monarch, a music venue in East Williamsburg, the 1999 Smash Mouth hit “All Star” rang through the speakers to kick the party off around 10 p.m., causing the crowd to erupt into dancing and a singalong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: The Key Insights From Our First Poll of the 2022 Midterms
description: A summary of the findings includes deep dissatisfaction among voters and potential fertile ground for new candidates in 2024.
content: Which side has the most energy heading into November? More polls will come as the midterm elections near, but for now we’ve wrapped up our first New York Times/Siena survey, and here are some notable takeaways:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It’s All on the Table
description: Greg Slovacek’s debut puzzle will hold you in thrall.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This is one for the books. Greg Slovacek is a software engineer from San Francisco; this is his first published crossword. He finds puzzlemaking similar, in a way, to programming — both involve problem-solving within constraints — and he enjoys puzzles that have layers for a solver to uncover.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Initiate Post Production?
description: Kameron Austin Collins rescues us with an endearing Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I always expect a challenge when I see Kameron Austin Collins’s byline, but I got into a nice flow working on this grid (though I’d never presume to be getting good at this, especially after last Saturday) and found its personality more amiable than angsty. Mr. Collins makes wonderfully creative themeless grids, full of catchy trivia references and thousand-dollar words. This puzzle also has several humorous touches that are worth a second look, if you’ve done well on your first round of solving.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Ian Black
title: What’s Wrong (and Sometimes Right) With American Men?
description: Isaac Fitzgerald’s “Dirtbag, Massachusetts” is a memoir about male misbehavior and the struggle to make sense of oneself.
content: Forgive us men, for we have sinned. Some of us more than others, few of us as prodigiously and joyfully as Isaac Fitzgerald, whose new memoir, “Dirtbag, Massachusetts,” chronicles his upbringing as the accidental byproduct of sin between two divinity students; his turbulent and violent childhood; his years of drugging, day drinking, scrapping, bartending and acting in porn; along with a sideline of missionary work in two Southeast Asian war zones. He describes his book as a “confessional,” although the only actual scene of confession we get is when young Isaac describes an early sexual encounter to an overly alert priest, who Isaac later suspects was masturbating while listening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Putin Aims to Shape a New Generation of Supporters, Through Schools
description: Sweeping changes in the curriculum will soon cast the Russian president as a pivotal historical figure and mark an end of openness to the West.
content: Starting in first grade, students across Russia will soon sit through weekly classes featuring war movies and virtual tours through Crimea. They will be given a steady dose of lectures on topics like “the geopolitical situation” and “traditional values.” In addition to a regular flag-raising ceremony, they will be introduced to lessons celebrating Russia’s “rebirth” under President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Irish Eyes Aren’t Smiling
description: A nation once in the grip of religious extremism sadly watches America’s lurch to the right on abortion.
content: GALWAY, Ireland — I came to Ireland four years ago to cover the searing story of the Scarlet Letter in the Emerald Isle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Lily Safra, Star-Crossed Socialite and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
description: Her life was marked by tragedy, including the bizarre death of her fourth husband, but that did not stop her from giving away millions.
content: Lily Safra, a Brazilian-born socialite and philanthropist who led a star-filled, star-crossed life with enough jet-setting ups and tragedy-filled downs to fill a dozen Danielle Steel novels, including the bizarre death of her fourth husband, the banker Edmond J. Safra, died on July 9 at her home in Geneva. She was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of July 11, 2022.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Turbulence on the Ground at Toronto’s Pearson Airport
description: Airports around the world are struggling to keep pace with the summer travel boom.
content: The disorder at Toronto Pearson International Airport was visible from the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: 6 Months Into Term, Eric Adams Raises $850,000 for Re-election in 2025
description: Mayor Eric Adams has traveled across the country to court donors, receiving contributions from casino and sports betting executives.
content: When Mayor Eric Adams was confronted last month with troubling poll numbers, he gave an optimistic interpretation: He said he had earned a C grade from many New Yorkers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: The World Economy Is Imperiled by a Force Hiding in Plain Sight
description: Well more than two years into the worst pandemic in a century, the accompanying economic shock continues to assault global fortunes.
content: This past week brought home the magnitude of the overlapping crises assailing the global economy, intensifying fears of recession, job losses, hunger and a plunge on stock markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Passengers Sigh as Heathrow Caps Numbers to Head Off ‘Airmageddon’
description: After two years of pandemic-enforced staycations, demand for travel has come roaring back in Europe, and airports are finding it impossible to keep up.
content: HEATHROW — The travelers’ destinations were varied: a hotly anticipated vacation in Amsterdam, a conference in Ohio, a family reunion in Austria.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Says He Confronted Saudi Prince Over Khashoggi. How True Is That?
description: Mr. Biden is by nature a storyteller with a history of relating dramatic tales of conversations with foreign leaders that others in the room do not recall the same way.
content: JEDDAH, Saudi Arabia — As President Biden told the tale, it sounded pretty dramatic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leah C. Stokes
title: What Joe Manchin Cost Us
description: Mr. Manchin’s legacy will be climate destruction.
content: Over the last year and a half, I’ve dissected every remark I could find in the press from Senator Joe Manchin on climate change. With the fate of our planet hanging in the balance, his every utterance was of global significance. But his statements have been like a weather vane, blowing in every direction. It’s now clear that Mr. Manchin has wasted what little time this Congress had left to make real progress on the climate crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger
title: Moscow Signals a Shift to a More Aggressive Phase of Ukraine War
description: After a brief pause, the Russian military is ramping up activity “in all operational sectors” in the Donbas region, the defense minister said.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — In an indication that Russian forces were ending what they called an operational pause in their invasion of Ukraine, the defense minister of Russia, Sergei K. Shoigu, on Saturday ordered his forces to intensify attacks “in all operational sectors” of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Biden’s Mideast efforts on oil have a precedent: Jimmy Carter’s.
description: Jimmy Carter flew to Tehran in 1977 to meet the shah of Iran.
content: When President Biden met Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia in Jeddah on Friday, he was following in the footsteps of presidents like Jimmy Carter, who flew to Tehran in 1977 to exchange toasts with the shah of Iran on New Year’s Eve.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Sharp Drop in Global Childhood Vaccinations Imperils Millions of Lives
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, July 16, 2022.
content: “Parents don’t know the impact of measles, or of polio, so they start to pick and choose vaccinations. Parents are choosing not to do polio. They say, ‘It’s been 30 years with no polio, so do I need to do this?’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: M.L.B. to Pay $185 Million Settlement in Minor League Wage Dispute
description: The agreement provides only a modest sum to most players but could speed up the overhaul of how minor leaguers are compensated in the future.
content: Major League Baseball agreed to pay $185 million to settle a class-action lawsuit brought by thousands of current and former minor league players over past wage claims.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: Texas and Central Plains could see their hottest temperatures of the summer next week.
description: In much of the United States, it’s hot out there. Still.
content: In much of the United States, it’s hot out there. Still.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: An unspoken result of Biden’s meeting with Prince Mohammed: A setback in the Khashoggi case.
description: President Biden’s dropping of his resistance to speak with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman seems to signal the end of official U.S. efforts to seek justice for the slain journalist.
content: Since entering the White House, President Biden had refused to meet with, and even speak to, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the de facto ruler of Saudi Arabia, seeking to punish him with ostracism for the grisly murder of the Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: You Asked, I Answer
description: Readers are curious about local government, cameras, cooking and more.
content: This weekend, I (along with the team that brings you this newsletter) thought it would be fun to do something a little different. Instead of writing another take or analysis, I’ll answer a few questions about myself — things you might be interested to know. These are the types of questions that I encounter on social media and that I often see whenever I do live chats or question and answer sessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: Another Pain Point in a Summer of Travel Woes: Getting a Passport
description: If you’re urgently in need of a new or updated passport, brace yourself: Options have narrowed — and it’s likely going to cost you.
content: It’s a summer of headaches for travelers: Airfares are surging, checked bags are disappearing, and flights are being canceled in record numbers. And now there’s another pain point to add to the mix. If you’re in need of a new or updated passport, your options are limited — and it’s likely going to cost you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: Forget Nostalgia. The Glory Days Are Now.
description: No need to pretend a past era of Michigan football was better than it was.
content: Memory, as we know, is fallible, heavily influenced by context and our experiences. Still, it does offer us a version of the past, a certain truthiness. But nostalgia? Nostalgia is a big fat liar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola and Kris Rhim
title: Here’s what to watch at the world Championships on Saturday.
description: Marcell Jacobs, the Tokyo Olympics gold medalist in the 100 meters, and Sifan Hassan, the Toyko Olympic gold medalist in the 10,000 meters, both return to the global stage.
content: Some of the biggest stars of the Tokyo Olympics will compete at Hayward Field in Eugene, Ore., on Saturday. Sifan Hassan, the dominant distance runner, is expected to make her return to global competition in the women’s 10,000 meters. And the Olympic gold medalist Lamont Marcell Jacobs of Italy will face a trio of American sprinters looking to sweep the men’s 100 meters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: A Middle Eastern Party Scene Is Thriving on Brooklyn’s Dance Floors
description: Several New York City parties offer spaces where anyone and everyone can let loose, come together and find comfort in Middle Eastern and North African music.
content: Just before midnight on a Friday in June, a short line formed outside Elsewhere, a music venue and nightclub in Bushwick, Brooklyn. Saphe Shamoun, one of the D.J.s performing that night, gingerly approached two women in the queue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Young
title: Wind, Of Course, Goethe and Shame
description: Our critic recommends old and new books.
content: Hello, readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Luke Broadwater
title: Little-Known Lawyer Pitched Trump on Extreme Plans to Subvert Election
description: The role of William J. Olson in advising the president in late 2020, which has not previously been disclosed, shows how fringe figures were influencing him at a critical time.
content: Around 5 in the afternoon on Christmas Day in 2020, as many Americans were celebrating with family, President Donald J. Trump was at his Mar-a-Lago home in Palm Beach, Fla., on the phone with a little-known conservative lawyer who was encouraging his attempts to overturn the election, according to a memo the lawyer later wrote documenting the call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Golf’s Birthplace Faces a Risky Future on a Warming Planet
description: The Old Course, site of this year’s British Open, could be more vulnerable to floodwaters in the coming decades. Other links courses are even more imperiled.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — It is the rare golfer who does not fret over weather that could wash out a round or starve shots of distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Did Nature Heal During the Pandemic ‘Anthropause’?
description: Covid precautions created a global slowdown in human activity — and an opportunity to learn more about the complex ways we affect other species.
content: In a typical spring, breeding seabirds — and human seabird-watchers — flock to Stora Karlsö, an island off the coast of Sweden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Head of Documenta Resigns Amid Antisemitism Scandal
description: A crisis at one of the world’s most important art events, in Germany, has deepened with the resignation of its director general.
content: After a month of crisis that has roiled the art world, Sabine Schormann, the director general of the renowned contemporary art exhibition Documenta, resigned on Saturday from her post only 28 days into the exhibition’s 100-day run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Could a Scot Please Win the British Open One Day? Is That Too Much to Ask?
description: The last golfer from Scotland to win the British Open was Paul Lawrie in 1999 at Carnoustie, and his victory was somewhat of a fluke.
content: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland — They were having fun, perhaps too much fun, on the Old Course on Saturday at the British Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Why Is the World’s Biggest Track Meet in a Small College Town in Oregon?
description: Eugene, Ore., has spent more than a century evolving into “TrackTown.” On Friday, the World Athletics Championships opened in this unlikely destination.
content: World championships in track and field generally take place in world capitals. Rome, Beijing, Moscow, Paris and London have all taken a turn hosting the biggest event in the sport other than the Olympic Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Kirsch
title: Salad Days
description: When it comes to making the perfect summer salad, sometimes less is more.
content: I have spent more kitchen hours than I care to admit trying, in vain, to recreate the Caesar salad dressing of a certain Midtown Manhattan lunch spot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gilberto Neto, José Bautista and Lynsey Chutel
title: Dead but Not Buried, Ex-President’s Body Sparks a Cross-Continental Fight
description: José Eduardo dos Santos ruled Angola for 38 years. But he died in Spain. A dispute over where to lay him to rest has divided his family and could decide the fate of his political party.
content: LUANDA, Angola — Even in death, Angola’s longtime ruler, José Eduardo dos Santos, is at the center of political infighting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel and Eduardo Medina
title: At Least 6 Killed in Montana Pileup During Dust Storm
description: More than 20 vehicles were involved after a windstorm caused “near-blackout” conditions, the authorities said.
content: At least six people were killed and others were injured in southern Montana in a major car pileup on Friday afternoon during a windstorm that kicked up dust and caused “near-blackout conditions,” the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Italy’s Crisis Redoubles European Foreboding
description: Europe is being tested, not only in its united front to Russia, but in the very resilience of its democracies, as nationalist forces sympathetic to Russia remain untamed.
content: An Italian government crisis, once so frequent as to be a near nonevent, has exposed the fragility of a Europe contending with rising energy prices, a plunging currency, faltering leadership, and a war in Ukraine where time appears to favor Russia’s autocratic resolve over the West’s democratic uncertainty.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karl Russell, Joe Rennison and Jason Karaian
title: The Dollar Is Extremely Strong, Pushing Down the World
description: The value of the U.S. dollar is the strongest it has been in a generation, devaluing other currencies and unsettling the global economic outlook.
content: The value of the U.S. dollar is the strongest it has been in a generation, devaluing other currencies and unsettling the global economic outlook.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read William J. Olson’s Memo to Trump
description: William J. Olson, a right-wing lawyer, sent a memo in December 2020 to President Donald J. Trump on how to seek to overturn the election.
content: William J. Olson, a right-wing lawyer, sent a memo in December 2020 to President Donald J. Trump on how to seek to overturn the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Citrin
title: A Body of One’s Own
description: My daughter’s life (and mine) in a post-Roe world.
content: My daughter’s life (and mine) in a post-Roe world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Allison McCann and Josh Holder
title: Egypt’s Revolving Jailhouse Door: One Pretrial Detention After Another
description: An analysis of handwritten records shows that thousands of Egyptians have been detained without charge, sometimes for years.
content: An analysis of handwritten records shows that thousands of Egyptians have been detained without charge, sometimes for years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 16, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, July 16, 2022.
content: An article on Friday about the story of a 10-year-old girl in Ohio who crossed state lines to get an abortion and became a flash point in the national abortion debate misstated Bill O’Reilly’s connection to The First, a conservative media outlet. He is a host for the outlet, not the owner.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What Turns a Person Into a Mass Shooter?
description: Readers discuss a column by David Brooks that focuses on alienation and other social and psychological factors.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times
